awd_titl_txt: Probing the Epoch of Reionization by Intensity Mapping Ionized Carbon ([CII]) with TIME-Pilot
awd_abstract_narration:
Abigail Crites is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at the California Institute of Technology. Crites will work on the development of the Tomographic Ionized Carbon Intensity Mapping Experiment (TIME-Pilot), a new instrument designed to measure signatures of ionized carbon in the early universe. This new instrument will improve our understanding of the history of star formation during a poorly studied period when the universe was evolving rapidly. The planned measurements will constrain the density of star formation and establish the technique of ionized carbon detection as a new, viable way of probing the early history of the forming universe. Alongside this work, Crites will conduct an outreach effort that first includes visits to Los Angeles area public high schools to provide a broad introduction to science, followed by bringing 1 - 2 students to work in the TIME-Pilot group's laboratory during the summer. 

The Tomographic Ionized Carbon Intensity Mapping Experiment (TIME-Pilot) is a new cryogenic, mm-wavelength spectrometer designed to measure clustering fluctuations in the 157.7 micrometer ionized carbon [CII] emission line during the Epoch of Reionization (EoR) and carbon monoxide in the epoch of peak star formation rate.  This will be accomplished through intensity mapping of [CII] in order to detect clustering fluctuations and test the predicted [CII] amplitudes of faint emission from the earliest dwarf galaxies. A [CII] detection with TIME-Pilot would constrain the density of EoR star formation and would make [CII] emission a viable new tool for understanding the EoR. Crites will focus on both completing the development of the TIME-Pilot instrument and conducting an analysis of the systematic effects from the foreground that will need to be accommodated in order to extract the [CII] signal. High school students in the outreach program will receive classroom visits describing the practice of science, followed by a small number of students being invited to work with the TIME-Pilot group's laboratory for hands-on experience during the summer.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was to build an instrument to measure the ionized carbon ([CII]) emitted during the epoch of reionization (EoR). This cryogenic instrument is a grating spectrometer with 2000 transition edge sensor (TES) bolometers able to make very sensitive measurements of signals from the early universe. The instrument will be used to make the measurement using a technique called line intensity mapping (LIM) which maps the intensity of the emission from this ionized carbon line over a large patch of the sky. This measurement will tell us about star formation during this early epoch in the history of our universe. 

During this three year fellowship, design and fabrication of various components of the instrument were completed and the project culminated with the installation of the instrument for an engineering test. The broader impacts and intellectual merit were deeply connected as this was a collaborative project designed to bring students from all levels from high school to graduate school together to learn about scientific research and complete this instrument. In particular this project involved bringing ?Cosmology Interns? to Caltech from high schools and a local community college to work together to complete the objectives. In the first year the design for the optics, detectors and other hardware was completed. In the second year, fabrication, assembly and testing of the instrument was done. In the third year the fabrication and assembly continued and final testing in preparation for installing the instrument on the telescope was completed where the instrument optics, detector and readout noise, and data acquisition software were tested and characterized. 

Over the course of this project significant progress was made toward making a pioneering measurement of star formation in the early universe using line intensity mapping of emission from ionized carbon. The fellowship also contributed significantly to the growth of a diverse STEM workforce: 5 undergraduates, 2 high school students, and 4 graduate students were mentored by the fellow in research methods, mechanical and optical design, and cryogenic hardware development during the course of this project, and this fellowship also empowered the growth of the PI of this fellowship from postdoctoral researcher to PI and leader of the TIME project as a whole. The hardware development and workforce growth supported by this fellowship laid the groundwork for the next steps forward in the field of line intensity mapping and will enable future observations of the early universe with this unique technique using ionized carbon line emission.
